Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: How Do Cilia-driven Flows Shape the Chemical and Mechanical Environment in Bacteria-Host Associations?

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an INSPIRE award that was co-funded by the Biosciences Directorate, Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB), Systems and Synthetic Biology (SSB) program, and the Engineering Directorate, Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation (CMMI), Dynamics, Control and System Diagnostics (DCSD) program.

Beneficial and pathogenic bacteria alike, commonly interact with host cells along mucosal epithelia. These surfaces are often lined with dense fields of motile cilia that serve both a biomechanical function for generating mucociliary flows, and a biochemical function to detect and present molecular signals. The goal of this project is to investigate a the dynamic association of healthy and diseased ciliated tissues. The project posits that cilia-generated flows influence bacteria-host interactions, thereby challenging the conventional view in biology that attributes bacterial recruitment mostly to active bacterial behavior and passive diffusion, ignoring the effect of cilia-generated flows on both motility and mass transport. The broader impacts of this study are that this project provides excellent educational and training opportunities at the intersection of disciplines, while also generating new insight in microbial host colonization that are likely to reveal avenues for impactful strategies to block pathogenic bacteria from colonizing the host, while enhancing the colonization potential of beneficial organisms.

The approach incorporates interdisciplinary methods, ranging from cutting-edge imaging and genetic tools to novel microfluidic technologies, all combined with powerful mathematical and computational framework, to investigate this fundamental problem in bacteria-host associations, namely, the role of cilia-generated flows in shaping these associations. The project will build a quantitative and predictive model that is informed by experimental assays in two complementary model systems:
1. In vivo invertebrate model: the squid-vibrio system, an intact animal host operating in its natural fluid environment, will be used to study how the host's ciliated epithelium initiates contact with its native, flow-borne bacterial community. Events in the squid-vibrio association share remarkable similarities with host responses to human-relevant pathogens, while still being accessible to imaging and experimental manipulation.
2. In silico microfluidics: properly designed microfluidic channels will be used as a tool to analyze the response of bacterial cells to carefully controlled microenvironment. This approach is aimed at complementing the squid-vibrio studies by providing a platform that isolates the chemical gradients and flow shear gradients observed in the in vivo model, thus allowing to unravel the mechanisms dictating bacterial behavior and possibly triggering the changes in bacterial gene expressions causing the transition from free-swimming to biofilm state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The alliances between host tissues and microbial partners occur often along mucosal epithelia, as in the human upper airways, which also constitute the first defense against environmentally transmitted pathogens. These surfaces are lined by dense fields of motile cilia – slender hair-like structures extending from the cell surface – that serve a dual bio-mechanical and bio-chemical function, of generating mucociliary flows and detecting and presenting chemical signals. Both functions are essential for healthy bacteria-host associations. Disruptions in the ciliary apparatus, whether due to genetic disorder or infectious agents, are directly linked to disease. The prevalent thought process is that proper functioning of cilia is crucial for the secretion and transport of mucus, whose role is to maintain a strict barrier to environmental particles and bacteria, and that ineffective clearance of mucus creates an ideal culture medium for bacteria, and thus leads to infection and disease. However, ciliated surfaces seem to also provide an entryway and habitat for co-evolved symbionts, suggesting that the view of a strict barrier function to mucociliary flows is too simplistic.

In this INSPIRE grant, we examined the flow physics of ciliated tissues in association with environmental bacteria and demonstrated that mucociliary membranes can create fluid-mechanical microenvironments for the active recruitment of the specific microbiome of the host, thus challenging the conventional view of a strict barrier function to mucociliary flows.

Mucosal tissues in the upper airways, for example, are home to complex microbial consortia containing but are inaccessible to observation. Such tissues can be directly examined in aquatic animals, providing valuable opportunities for the analysis of mucociliary activity in relation to bacteria recruitment. Using the squid–vibrio model system, we provided a characterization of the initial engagement of microbial symbionts along ciliated tissues. Specifically, we developed imaging techniques, together with empirical and theoretical methods, to conduct a census of ciliated cell types, create structural maps, and resolve spatiotemporal flow dynamics generated by the host ciliated tissues. Our multiscale analyses revealed two distinct, highly organized populations of cilia on the host tissues of the squid. An array of long cilia (~25 μm) with metachronal beat creates a flow that focuses bacteria-sized particles, at the exclusion of larger particles, into sheltered zones; there, a field of randomly beating short cilia (~10 μm) mixes the local fluid environment, which contains host biochemical signals known to prime symbionts for colonization. This cilia-mediated process represents a previously unrecognized flow-based mechanism for symbiont recruitment. 

Together with this major discovery, we made contributions in the following areas. 

(1) We developed in-vivo experimental assays using the squid-vibrio system and in-vitro microfluidic assays for quantifying cilia-driven flows using Particle Image Velocimetry techniques and examining bacterial behavior in flows. 

(2) We developed light field microscopy (LFM) for visualizing fast 3-dimensional (3D) flow patterns in which a 2D camera captures the complete spatial angular information of a visual scene and computation is applied to reconstruct the 3D visual scene. To solve the problem of low signal contrast of conventional LFM, we developed a methodology that allows us to illuminate only the parts of the sample that are of interest and avoid lighting up the extraneous parts of the sample, thus removing the background signal that normally would generate the background that degrade the real signal. We term our methodology Selective Volume Illumination Microscopy (SVIM).

(3) We developed physics-based mathematical models that understanding and characterizing the physics of (i) cilia oscillations, (ii) coordination between neighboring cilia, and (iii) ciliated-tissue morphology and cilia-driven flows. In addition to their roles in clarifying experimental observations, these models serve to present and test new hypotheses on the multi-scale physics and role of cilia and cilia-driven flows in the biological function of mucociliary surfaces.

Each mucociliary surface that recruits a microbiome is likely to have system-specific features. However, all mucociliary surfaces are subject to the same physical and biological constraints that are imposed by the fluid environment and the evolutionary conserved structure of cilia. Our findings promise to provide insight into universal mechanisms that drive the recruitment of symbiotic partners. 

This INSPIRE project provided opportunities for the training and professional development of post-docs and graduate students from complementary disciplines (biology, flow physics, microscopy). We mentored them on sound scientific methodologies for creating research questions, designing experiments, developing models, and conducting research. We also provided training in scientific writing and presentations. For undergraduates, the project provided exposure to research topics at the interface of fluid mechanics and biology and hands-on experience in a wet lab environment.  Research results were disseminated online and in scientific conferences and per-refereed journal publications, and were highlighted in dozens of media and scientific news outlets including the Howard Hughes Medical Institute Image of the Day and Image of the Week.
